content:
School Overview
Basic Information
Haberdashers' Boys' School (Habs Boys)
Butterfly Lane, Elstree, Hertfordshire, WD6 3AF
Tel: 020 8266 1700
Type: Independent boys' school, ages 4-18
Part of Haberdashers' Elstree Schools on a 100-acre co-educational campus shared with Habs Girls.
Source: School Homepage
Awards
- Independent School of the Year 2025 (overall winner)
- Independent School of the Year for Outstanding Educational Partnerships
Source: School Homepage
School Structure
Division: Year Groups: Ages: Details

Prep School: Reception - Year 6: 4-11: 300+ boys; 2 classes/year (R-Y2), 3 classes/year (Y3-6)
Senior School: Years 7-11: 11-16: Core academic programme
Sixth Form: Years 12-13: 16-18: Some co-taught classes with Habs Girls
Source: Prep School Life

Vision and Values

Core Statements
Vision: To be at the forefront of education
Mission: Two leading schools on one co-educational campus for ambitious and curious students; offering outstanding education that is fun, exciting and intellectually challenging, developing independence, resilience and a moral compass to create positive change.
Purpose: To empower young people to make a profound impact in the world.
Source: Our Vision

Four Core Values
1. AMBITIOUS
Bold and ambitious for students, staff, and the world. Underpinned by philanthropic foundations. Students stretch boundaries, challenge status quo. When combined with courage, curiosity and community, ambition becomes a selfless lever for change.
2. CURIOUS
Engage with the world by questioning, challenging assumptions, expressing ideas. Curriculum encourages imagination, creativity, spirituality, bringing awe and wonder to learning.
3. COURAGEOUS
Explore beyond comfort zones to become self-aware, adventurous, resilient, independent. Cope well with setbacks. Balance humility and boldness. Unflinching problem-solvers seeking to change the world.
4. COMMUNITY
One caring, respectful community extending to families, alumni, partner schools, Haberdashers' Company, and the world. Focus on belonging, inclusivity, celebrating differences. Learning from and working with communities locally, nationally, globally.
Source: Our Vision

Habs Student Profile
Ambitious, globally curious, tolerant, resilient, compassionate, kind, altruistic. Orchestrates compelling conversations. Initiates change. Strong moral compass. Determined to make a difference. Community-focused. #ProfoundImpact
Source: Our Vision

Admissions
Entry Points
- 4+ (Reception)
- 7+ (Year 3)
- 11+ (Year 7)
- 13+ (Year 9)
- 16+ (Sixth Form)
- Occasional places in other years
Contact: admissionsboys@habselstree.org.uk
Source: Admissions Process

4+ Reception Entry
Key Dates (2025-26)
Milestone: Date

Registration deadline: Thursday 20 November 2025
Play-based assessment: Monday 15 – Wednesday 17 December 2025
Second round assessment: Monday 12 – Tuesday 20 January 2026
Offers sent out: Monday 26 January 2026
Offer holders' day: Thursday 29 January 2026
Offer acceptance deadline: Wednesday 4 February 2026 (12pm)
Requirements
- Age 4 by 1 September in year of entry
- ~40 places offered annually
Process
1. Play-based assessment (1.5 hours) - individual/group activities
2. Nursery reference requested
3. Second round - selected candidates, one-to-one assessment (1 hour) with senior staff
4. Parent meeting with Head of Prep
Source: Admissions Process

7+ Year 3 Entry
Key Dates (2025-26)
Milestone: Date

Registration deadline: Thursday 6 November 2025
Formal assessment: Friday 21 November 2025
Second round assessments: Wednesday 17 December 2025
Offers sent out: Friday 23 January 2026
Offer holders' day: Friday 30 January 2026
Offer acceptance deadline: Wednesday 4 February 2026 (12pm)
Requirements
- Age 7 by 1 September in year of entry
- ~26 places (three-form entry, ~22/class)
Process
1. Formal assessment - Reasoning, Maths, English
2. Second round (~50% invited) - English and STEM assessment
3. Parent meeting with Head of Prep
Source: Admissions Process

11+ Year 7 Entry
Key Dates (2025-26)
Milestone: Date

Registration/Scholarship deadline: Thursday 6 November 2025
Bursary deadline: Friday 21 November 2025
First round assessment: Tuesday 18 & Friday 21 November 2025
Second round assessment: Tuesday 13 - 20 January 2026
Offers sent (post): Thursday 12 February 2026
Offers sent (email): Friday 13 February 2026
Offer holders' day: Thursday 26 February 2026
Offer acceptance deadline: Wednesday 4 March 2026 (12pm)
Requirements
- Age 11 by 1 September in year of entry
- ~100 external places
Assessment Components
Online Adaptive Tests:
- Maths (20 min)
- Non-Verbal Reasoning (10 min)
- Verbal Reasoning (10 min)
- Puzzles/Problem-Solving (15 min, non-adaptive)
- English inc. creative comprehension (50 min, non-adaptive)
Handwritten:
- Creative writing (30 min, offline)
Based on Key Stage 2 National Curriculum
Familiarisation Test: http://app.questassessments.com/public/taster/habs-elstree
Interviews
- ~50% invited based on exam results
- Parent meeting with leadership team
11+ Deferred Entry
Students can sit 11+ exam and defer entry to Year 9 (age 13). No further tests required, satisfactory Headteacher reference needed.
Source: Admissions Process

13+ Year 9 Entry
Key Dates (2025-26)
Milestone: Date

Registration/Scholarship deadline: Thursday 6 November 2025
Bursary deadline: Friday 28 November 2025
First round assessment: Friday 28 November 2025
Second round assessment: Wednesday 21 January 2026
Offers sent out (posted): Thursday 12 February 2026
Offer holders' day: Tuesday 24 February 2026
Conditional acceptance deadline: Thursday 26 February 2026 (12pm)
Requirements
- Age 13 by 1 September in year of entry
- ~20 external places
Assessment
Written exams in:
- English
- Maths
- Humanities (History, Geography, Theology & Philosophy)
- Science (Biology, Chemistry, Physics)
Successful candidates invited for interview.
Source: Admissions Process

16+ Sixth Form Entry
Key Dates (2025-26)
Milestone: Date

Registration/Scholarship deadline: Monday 20 October 2025
Bursary deadline: Tuesday 4 November 2025
Entrance assessment: Tuesday 4 November 2025
Interview: Monday 17 November 2025
Conditional offers sent: Thursday 4 December 2025
Offer acceptance deadline: Friday 12 December 2025
Requirements
- Age 16 by 1 September in year of entry
- Nine GCSEs including Maths and English
GCSE Grade Requirements for A-Level Subjects
Subject(s): Requirement

Most subjects: Min Grade 7 (or Grade 7 in related subject if new)
Maths, Biology, Chemistry, Physics: Grade 8 essential (Grade 9 recommended)
Further Maths: Strong Grade 9
Economics, Computing: Grade 8 in Maths (Grade 9 recommended)
Philosophy, Politics: Grade 8 in related subject (RS, English, History) recommended
Assessment
1. One-hour general paper (past papers available)
2. One-hour Maths paper (for STEM students)
3. Structured subject interviews for successful candidates
4. Headteacher report and predicted grades requested
Source: Admissions Process

Occasional Places & International
Occasional places for non-standard year groups assessed end Feb/early Mar for Sept entry. Assessment includes English, Maths, interview.
International students: Not licensed as Child Student sponsor - all UK study permissions must be independently arranged.
Source: Admissions Process

Admissions FAQs
- Tutoring: Not recommended for 4+/7+ entry
- Sibling preference: None - each child assessed individually
- State school applicants: Equal intake from state/independent schools
- 11+ preparation: Based on Key Stage 2, no tutoring needed
Source: Admissions Process

Fees and Financial Support
Tuition Fees 2025-26
All fees include 20% VAT from January 2025
Year Group: Termly (ex VAT): Termly (inc VAT): Annual

Tuition: Pre-Prep (Reception-Year 2): £7,011: £8,413: £25,239
Tuition: Prep (Years 3-6): £8,208: £9,849: £29,547
Tuition: Senior School (Years 7-11): £8,686: £10,423: £31,269
Tuition: Sixth Form (Years 12-13): £8,686: £10,423: £31,269
Fees include: Stationery, textbooks, apparatus, accident/dental insurance. Prep fees include lunch.
Additional charges: Devices (£125/term, Y7+), Senior lunch (£5.25/day, optional), trips, music lessons.
Payment: Three termly instalments by direct debit. Full term's notice required for withdrawal.
Acceptance deposit: 50% of term's fees (returned when child completes Habs).
Source: Fees

VAT Treatment (from Jan 2025)
VAT @20% Applied To:
- Fees
- Devices
- Prep lunch (included in fees)
- Music lessons
- Educational clubs
VAT Exempt:
- Senior lunch (optional)
- Home-to-school coach
- Educational trips
- Childcare clubs
- Exam fees
Fees In Advance: Post-29 July 2024 subject to VAT. Pre-29 July 2024 may be exempt but under HMRC scrutiny.
Source: Fees

Additional Costs
Device Rental
£125/term (Years 7-12)
Music Lessons (inc VAT)
Type: Cost per Term

Individual lessons: £373
Group lessons: £228
Group Aural/Theory: £120
Instrument hire: £51
Available instruments: Bassoon, Cello, Clarinet, Double Bass, Drums, Euphonium, Flute, French Horn, Guitar (Classical/Electric/Jazz), Harmonium, Oboe, Organ, Piano, Saxophone, Tabla, Trombone, Trumpet, Tuba, Viola, Violin, Voice, Dhol, Dholak
Source: Fees

Payment Options
1. Termly direct debit - standard payment method
2. Monthly School Fee Plan - Premium Credit
3. Fees In Advance (FIA) - 3.50% discount (~4.16% annual return for higher-rate taxpayers). Lump sum held until exhausted.
4. School Fees Refund Scheme - 0.82% of fees/term. Claim for illness/accident absences (5+ days). Claims within 30 days of term end.
Contact: feesboys@habselstree.org.uk
Source: Fees

Bursaries (Means-Tested Financial Support)
Available for: 11+, 13+, 16+ entry
For families who cannot afford fees despite benefitting from Habs. Place must be offered first based on academic merit. Requires confidential income statement. Can combine with scholarships.
Application Deadlines
Entry Point: Deadline

11+: Friday 21 November 2025
13+: Friday 28 November 2025
16+: Tuesday 4 November 2025
Source: Admissions Process, Fees

Scholarships
Available for: 11+, 13+, 16+ entry
Categories:
- Academic
- Art
- Design Technology
- Drama
- Music
- Sport
VAT charged only on amount paid by parents (e.g., 10% scholarship = VAT on 90% paid by parents)
Can combine with bursaries
Application Deadlines
Entry Point: Deadline

11+: Thursday 6 November 2025
13+: Thursday 6 November 2025
16+: Monday 20 October 2025
Source: Admissions Process

Prep School (Ages 4-11)
Overview
300+ day boys, ages 4-11
Entry points: 4+ (Reception) or 7+ (Year 3)
Progression: Reception entrants progress automatically to Year 3, then Senior School after Year 6 (no 11+ exam required)
Source: Prep School Life

Educational Philosophy
Fun at heart of education. Awe and wonder inspire curiosity. Develop well-rounded individuals excelling academically while passionate about sport, music, arts. Challenge comfort zones, build resilience.
Focus areas:
- Strong moral compass
- Empathy
- Solution-creation
- Leadership via values, charity, assemblies, PSHE
Positively-worded Code of Conduct emphasizes personal responsibility, learning from mistakes, restorative justice.
Source: Prep School Life

Single-Sex with Co-Ed Opportunities
Boys-only classes free from gender expectations.
Shared Activities with Habs Girls
Reception - Year 2:
- Some playtimes
- Joint musical workshops
- Forest School
- Egg hunts
- Teddy bears' picnics
Years 3-6:
- Some lunch/playtimes
- Script-writing
- Maths workshops
- Planetarium
- Joint choir
- Lunchtime Live performances
- Sports festivals
Source: Prep School Life

School Day Schedule
Time: Activity

7:30am: Breakfast club (Girls' School)
8:00am: School grounds open
8:30-8:45am: Registration
8:45am-4:00pm: Periods 0-9 (incl. breaks/lunch)
4:00-5:30pm: After-school activities/care
4:15pm: Coaches depart (regular)
5:30pm: Late coaches depart
Source: Prep School Life

Wraparound Care
Provider: Premier Education
Hours: After-school to 6:00pm Mon-Fri
Includes: Light snack
Bookings: 24hrs advance (or midday same day subject to availability). Book ad hoc or regular weekly.
Payment: Card, instalments, childcare vouchers, tax-free childcare
Contact: info@premier-education.com, 01953 499040
Booking: https://www.premier-education.com/
Source: Prep School Life

Senior School (Years 7-11, Ages 11-16)
Overview
Ambitious, challenging, exciting curriculum. Expert teachers stretch students while sharing subject passion. Active, independent learning with practical tasks, discussion, debate. Students encouraged to take risks, investigate, explore.
Expected to excel across: Languages, sciences, maths, athletics, music, performing arts, technology, history, arts.
Source: Senior School - Inside the Classroom

Curriculum Structure
Not bound by National Curriculum but stays current with developments. Ambitious, innovative, broad, balanced - all subjects equally important.
By Year Group
Year 7:
- French, Spanish, German carousel
- Choose 2 languages in Year 8
Years 7-9:
- Set but flexible curriculum
Higher years:
- Greater personalisation to suit needs/interests
- Up to 4 optional GCSE subjects
Throughout:
- Extended research projects (Family History Y7, academic papers later)
Additional opportunities:
- National/international competitions (Maths/Science olympiads)
- External speakers
- Academic societies
Source: Senior School - Inside the Classroom

Transitions
Lower School (Y7-8) → Middle School (Y9-11) → Sixth Form
Bespoke one-to-one guidance at each stage, especially for GCSE/A-Level choices. Mid-senior school, staff begin helping students think about interests, university, career ambitions. Close monitoring of academic progress and wellbeing enables partnerships with parents for right decisions.
Source: Senior School - Inside the Classroom

GCSE Results
Challenge students beyond exam curricula. Excel in exams and co-curricular/partnership commitments. Broad curriculum develops personal skills/attributes.
Single-sex education to GCSEs, benefiting from co-ed setting.
Recent Academic Results (2024)
Grade: Percentage

Grade 9: 53%
Grades 9-8 (A equivalent): 78%
Grades 9-7 (A-A equivalent): 91.5%
Leavers' Destinations: High proportion of students progress to Russell Group universities and Oxbridge.
Historical results 2016-2025 available as PDFs on website.
Source: GCSE Results

Sixth Form (Years 12-13, Ages 16-18)
Overview
Ambitious, challenging, outstanding education. Global perspective throughout. Students lead, succeed, impact world.
Learning approach:
- Independent and collaborative
- Practical tasks, discussion, debate
- Develop soft skills: teamwork, confidence, communication, flexibility, empathy, leadership
Source: Sixth Form - Inside the Classroom

A-Level Programme
Choose 3-4 A-Levels over 2 years
At least 1 taught in mixed-gender classes with Habs Girls
Available A-Level Subjects
Art, Biology, Chemistry, Classical Civilisation, Classical Greek, Computer Science, Design & Technology, Drama, Economics, English Language, English Literature, French, Further Maths, Geography, German, History, Latin, Maths, Music, PE, Philosophy, Physics, Politics, Psychology, Religious Studies, Spanish
Can study without prior GCSE
Entry requirement: 9 GCSEs inc. Maths and English (see admissions section for specific grade requirements)
Source: Sixth Form - Inside the Classroom

Habs Diploma
On top of A-Levels. Soon accredited by University of Buckingham.
Components
1. Subject enhancement course
2. Six elective courses
3. Visiting speaker programme
4. Community service
5. Extended research project
Develops skills for university and life.
Source: Sixth Form - Inside the Classroom

Beyond the Classroom
- Trips, visits, speakers, experience days
- UK/international residential trips (curriculum and extra-curricular)
- Leadership development opportunities
- Sports, music, drama, clubs
- Combined Cadet Force (CCF)
- Duke of Edinburgh awards
- Diverse interests: calligraphy, water polo, birdwatching, politics
Source: Sixth Form - Inside the Classroom

University & Career Preparation
Heavy investment in university preparation. Support throughout Y12-13 with applications. Career advice/guidance shapes university and subject decisions.
Source: Sixth Form - Inside the Classroom

Sport and Co-Curricular
Sport Overview
~160 co-curricular sports beyond timetable. All students encouraged to participate (competitive, recreational, fun, wellbeing, social).
When: Lunchtimes, after school, weekends
Staff: Large sports staff team + visiting specialists
Source: Sport

Seasonal Focus
Term: Sports

Autumn: Football, Rugby
Spring: Hockey
Summer: Cricket
Up to 6 teams/age group in weekly competitive action
Source: Sport

Additional Sports
Fitness suite, tennis, swimming, climbing, golf, squash, badminton, real tennis
HabsDash
Weekly 3.5km community run, Tuesday lunchtimes. Open to students/staff across both schools.
Source: Sport

Benefits
Builds confidence, resilience. Learn rules, safety, fair play, cope with success/failure. Develop teamwork: appreciate others' contributions, take individual responsibility. Establishes lifelong health, fitness, friendship patterns.
Source: Sport

High-Performance Sport
Coached Sessions
Cricket, football, hockey, rugby, water polo, swimming
Led by: Professional sportspeople + Athletic Development Leads
Partnerships
- Middlesex Cricket
- Watford Football
- Saracens Rugby
- Watford Waterpolo
Compete: District, county, national level
Perform at: StoneX, Lords stadiums
ISI Report 2022
"Students achieve excellent results regionally and nationally. Teams at quarter-final stage of national competitions in rugby and football."
Source: Sport

Facilities
100-acre campus includes:
Academic & Performance Buildings
- Aldenham House (Historic centerpiece, Grade II listed building)
- Seldon Music Hall (Music performances)
- Lime Tree Studios (Drama)
- The Habs Innovation Centre (STEM and technology)
Sports & Recreation
- The Medburn Centre (Sports complex)
- Senior gym
- Indoor swimming pool
- Fitness suite
- 7 outdoor netball courts
- 9 outdoor tennis courts
- Sports fields
Outdoor Education
- Forest School
- Wildwood Den
Source:** Sport, Prep School Life

Pastoral Care and House System
House System
The school is divided into six Houses, which provide pastoral support and a structure for competition (sports, drama, music, and the HabsDash).
Senior School Houses
House: Colour

Calverts: Orange
Hendersons: Red
Joblings: Green
Meadows: Purple
Russells: Light Blue
Strouts: Yellow
Prep School Houses
Named after Patron Saints:
- St George's
- St Patrick's
- St David's
- St Andrew's
Source: School Homepage

Governance and History
Founding
Rooted in philanthropic principles. Deep sense of community purpose. Attracts talent wanting to make meaningful world difference.
Source: Our Vision

Strategic Plan
10-year "Profound Impact" strategy (published Sept 2022)
Unite Habs Boys and Habs Girls under shared vision: single-sex education on co-ed campus
Six Strategic Aims
1. Learning
2. Caring
3. Exploring
4. Partnerships
5. Talent
6. Campus
Leading education to 2030+
Source: Our Vision

Affiliations
Part of Haberdashers' Company and Schools
Member organizations:
- ISI (Independent Schools Inspectorate)
- HMC (Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference)
- ISC (Independent Schools Council)
- GSA (Girls' Schools Association)
- IAPS (Independent Association of Prep Schools)
- ISBA (Independent Schools' Bursars Association)
- AGBIS (Association of Governing Bodies of Independent Schools)
Source: School Homepage

Recent Mergers
Two schools joined Haberdashers' Elstree family:
1. Lochinver House School
2. St Martin's School, Northwood (announced December 2025)
Source: School Homepage

Contact Information
Main Address
Haberdashers' Boys' School
Butterfly Lane
Elstree
Hertfordshire
WD6 3AF
Tel: 020 8266 1700

Email Contacts
Department: Email

Admissions: admissionsboys@habselstree.org.uk
Fees Office: feesboys@habselstree.org.uk
VAT Enquiries: VATenquiries@habselstree.org.uk

Online Systems
- Website: https://www.habselstree.org.uk/boys/
- Habs App: https://app.weduc.co.uk/
- SOCS Calendar: https://calendar.habselstree.org.uk/week.aspx?ID=129

Admissions Team
Name: Role

Avril Tooley: Director of Marketing, Communications and Admissions
Binnur Rogers: Admissions Registrar
Chantal Gilbert: Admissions
Jennifer Adams: Assistant Registrar
Source: Admissions Process, School Homepage
